text:

A teenage yob has been spared jail but banned from the Metrolink network after a US Army veteran was racially abused on a tram in Manchester city centre. 
Aaron Cauchi, 19, is the last of three young louts to be sentenced after university lecturer Juan Jasso was told to ‘get back to Africa’ just days after the Brexit vote in June last year. 
Juan Jasso, who has lived in this country for 18 years, became an unlikely internet sensation when video footage of him standing up to their shameful abuse emerged. 
Earlier this month Robert Molloy, 20, was jailed for 24 weeks after admitting a racially aggravated assault on Jasso. A court was told Robert Molloy, 20, Aaron Cauchi, 19, and a 16-year-old who cannot be named for legal reasons, had been up drinking all night and were ‘looking for trouble’ on the tram. 
After they got off the tram on Market Street they abused passer-by Alistair Lambert and threw a cigarette lighter at him. 
They yobs when on to spit at and threaten a third victim, Andrew Guest, as he cycled to work in Trafford later the same morning. 
Now Cauchi, of Spa Road, Little Hulton, Salford , has been brought to justice for his role. The teenager admitted two public order offences and assault. He pleaded guilty on a basis that he said only ‘get off the tram’ to Mr Jasso, approached Mr Lambert in an ‘aggressive manner’ and ran towards Mr Guest. Robert Molloy (Photo: Andy Stenning) Read More Islamic State fighter with links to Manchester 'carries out suicide bombing in Iraq' 
Cauchi’s solicitor Harold Smith said he played a ‘lesser role’ than Molloy in the ‘ugly incidents’ and ‘uttered no racial language’ on the tram. He said he said nothing to either Mr Lambert or Mr Guest. Mr Smith said Cauchi, who has just become a father, was not responsible for flicking the lighter at Mr Lambert or spitting at Mr Guest. 
He was jailed for 16 weeks, suspended for two years, and ordered to complete 300 hours of community service. Cauchi must also pay court costs of £400 and compensation to the victims. 
Chairman of the bench, Michael Evans, called the three incidents on June 28 an ‘alcohol-fuelled rampage across the city of Manchester causing fear and distress to others, including children.” 
Cauchi also received a criminal behaviour order for two years, which bans him from travelling on Metrolink services across Greater Manchester and associating with the other two defendants. Juan Jasso, who has lived in this country for 18 years, became an unlikely internet sensation when video footage of him standing up to their shameful abuse emerged. Mr Jasso - who was hailed as ‘Super Juan’ on social media - was applauded by other passengers after he told the three to mind their language. 
In a victim impact statement read out in court, Mr Jasso said their behaviour was ‘disgusting’ and said he wanted to ‘challenge them’ because children were on board. 
The court heard Mr Lambert was approached by all three of the yobs ‘with their chests sticking out’ after he was hit by the lighter. 
Mr Guest, who managed to cycle away after he was chased, said in his statement that he felt ‘disgusted’ after he was spat at and just wanted to go home to have a shower.
